USAID is co Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.8: Orphans and Vulnerable Children. Activities are aimed at improving the lives of orphans and other vulnerable children (OVC) affected by HIV/AIDS, and doing so in a measurable way. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. objectives

Measure Evaluation Phase IV – TBD will be used by PEPFAR Namibia to work with the GRN and key CSO to evaluate community-based programs and support Namibia in developing models of best practice community interventions. USAID Namibia has a clear and well defined vision for its role in transitioning PEPFAR from a service delivery model to a technical assistance and capacity building role. USAID is committed to this vision through a variety of innovative and best practice approaches that will ultimately improve country ownership. This mechanism will achieve the goals laid out in the PEPFAR Blueprint through identifying and achieving efficiencies and building a sustained national response based on effective best-practice community-based interventions. Rigorous evaluations will underscore the critical role of CSO in the HIV response in Namibia and will lead to increased resource mobilization. While CSO projects are mostly funded through international donors and implemented in conjunction with the MoHSS, there is a lack of evidence on the impact on improved HIV outcomes. This activity will support the following evaluations: Adherence and Retention Project; National OVC programs and; Key Population programs. Geographic coverage for these activities will include national technical assistance support to GRN and CSO and regional implementation throughout Namibia. Target population for evaluation will include stakeholders and sampled program recipients. The IM will become cost effective over time as evidence generated from these evaluations will support resource mobilization of CSO. A key component of all these evaluations implemented will be to ensure key stakeholders from CSO and GRN learn evaluation techniques and support evidence dissemination at national and regional levels.
